answers.answer: Your questions really need to be handled by a medical professional, we're not  equipped to make any remote guess and what you should do. I would sit down with your family doctor and go through all of your meds. I think when someone has more then one specialist on board, the primary care physician should be apprised of all meds.I have erosive GERD and moved over to pariet, which I think is Aciphex from Nexium due to the cost, as I have to take a high dose - my insurance company wouldn't cover the drug so it was 120/mo - the pariet is only 20/mo.  Bruxism has many causes including anxiety which can become a compulsive behaviour, Zoloft is notorious for causing bruxism as well. Maybe research all of your meds then sit down with your doctor, it could be from any of or a combination of all the drugs you are on or none of them. It's good to get a full yearly check-up as well.Much luck,LCC

question: I am taking 225mg Effexor XR daily and Aciphex daily.  I have had problems with bruxism, cracked and chipped teeth from it and the subsequent repairs this past year.  Now I have uncontrollable tongue movement, to the point of my toungue being raw and sore by the end of the day.  TDK has been noted for both Effexor and Aciphex, which do you think is the culprit?  Could there be a synergistic reaction going on with both drugs?  I can not do without the Aciphex as my GERD is absolutely terrible.  I have also been recently diagnosed with Adult onsest diabetes controlled with diet and glucophage.  Any insight into this problem? Which drug should I stop first to determine which is causing the problem?  I have been on Effexor for over 5 years, the Aciphex probably as long.  The dosage was increased to 225mg about a year ago.  I am 60, still work and can not face my patients (mental health worker) looking like a snake!
title: TDK, Effexor XR and/or Aciphex????
